Why does Ubuntu make my access my internet very slow and any other OS runs the internet fast?
GIgabit ethernet or 100MBit/s?
Gigabit or 100MBIt/s ethernet?
Okay.
Which is you network device? wlan0? something different?
I did get that. What is you network device for wlan?
Okay, a linksys. But what I need to know is the networking device name in Ubuntu.
You get a list of them (and their settings) when calling "ifconfig" on the comman line.
No problem. Just open a terminal, then enter "ifconfig"
THis will produce a list. In the first column, there are names like "eth0" or "lan0" or "ath0".
In the second column is a block with the settings of the device listed on the left.
I need the contents of the left column, so eth0, wlan0, lo, whatever shows up there.
Okay, eth0 and lo.
Below etho, is there some "inet address" followed by an IP address?
Great. Is that your wireless IP adress?
In that block, below the IP adress, there is a "MTU:" followed by a number. Which number? Probably 1500.
Okay. Then try "sudo ifconfig eth0 mtu 999" Please no typing errors.
This will lower your MTU (maximum transfer unit) to 999 bytes, which is a number guessed by random.
So ubuntu will sen smaller packages.
If this helps a bit, you can increase the number, close to 1500, till you get a good performance.
Some routers wil create empty packages when ubuntu sends 1500 bytes packages, which will slow down the transfer a lot.

If you did find the best value for your router, edit your connections via network manager (the signal strength symbol in the upper right panel) via right-click, in the first register card there is the setting "MTU".
Then the MTU will be restored after the next reboot.
